column8: Billy Goat Bore drill core DDH88BG5
column40: Data extracted from Figure 3. The Carawine Dolomite is only exposed in the NE part of the Hamersley Basin, where the Hamersley Group is thinner than in the depocenter; in the middle of the basin, the Paraburdoo Member of the Wittenoom Formation is exposed. The Carawine Dolomite is shallow-marine with stromatolites and occasionally evaporitic/subaerial conditions, while the Paraburdoo Member of the Wittenoom Formation is a deep-ramp setting. Lindsay and Brasier (2002) suggest that the Carawine Dolomite and the Paraburdoo Member of the Wittenoom Formation "formed part of a single deposition setting in which carbonates were generated in a proximal setting along the shallower northeastern margin of the basin (Carawine Platform) and dispersed to the southwest from the platform towards a prograding ramp in the deeper-water, rapidly subsiding main depocentre of the basin (Paraburdoo Member)". Conformably overlies either the Mara Mamba Iron Formation or the underlying Jeerinah Formation, suggesting the Mara Mamba Iron formation laps out or laterally interfingers with the upper Jeerinah Formation towards the basin margin (Lindsay and Brasier, 2002)

column2: Duck Creek Dolomite - Lindsay and Brasier (2002)
column40: Stratigraphically above the Wooly Dolomite. Including in the Wyloo Group Composite section to enforce superposition between formations.

column2: Duck Creek Dolomite - Wilson et al. (2010)
column40: Stratigraphically above the Wooly Dolomite. Section F is a local slumped/brecciated unit; excluding samples. Higher sampling resolution than the Lindsay and Brasier (2002) section; however, prioritizing the lower-resolution section (to reduce computational cost) since this succession was deposited significnatly after the end of the Lomagundi excursion.
GPS coordinates are for lowermost sample. Heights given in meters above base of the lower siliclastic-carbonate member of the Kungarra Formation. Included in Turee Creek Composite section.

Other Wittenoom Formation cores also preserve similar carbon isotope trends.

Location from Lindsay and Brasier (2002). Composite section includes HC1, HC2, and HC3; sections are hung on HC3 (most of HC1 is not correlated; excluding associated samples). Measured section is stratigraphically below the Meteorite Bore Member. Assigning section to a low priority level because Martindale et al. (2015) interpret unusually negative and highly variable carbon isotope values (up to 2 permil variability within individual samples, and up to 4 permil variability within individual stratigraphic horizons) as evidence of diagenesis.

Martindale et al. (2015) notes a 0 to 0.6 permil difference in d13C between light and dark laminae in different layers. Extracted location from map (Fig. 1). If included in the inference, ensure that superposition with Kungarra Formation is enforced.

Location extracted from map (Figure 1). Martindale et al. (2015) notes minimal difference between light and dark laminae.  If included in the inference, ensure that superposition with Kungarra Formation is enforced.

Heights in meters above top of Meteorite Bore Member. Using GPS coordinates for lowermost sample. If included in the inference, ensure that superposition with Kazput Formation is enforced.

Data extracted from Figure 4. The Carawine Dolomite is only exposed in the NE part of the Hamersley Basin, where the Hamersley Group is thinner than in the depocenter; in the middle of the basin, the Paraburdoo Member of the Wittenoom Formation is exposed. The Carawine Dolomite is shallow-marine with stromatolites and occasionally evaporitic/subaerial conditions, while the Paraburdoo Member of the Wittenoom Formation is a deep-ramp setting. Lindsay and Brasier (2002) suggest that the Carawine Dolomite and the Paraburdoo Member of the Wittenoom Formation "formed part of a single deposition setting in which carbonates were generated in a proximal setting along the shallower northeastern margin of the basin (Carawine Platform) and dispersed to the southwest from the platform towards a prograding ramp in the deeper-water, rapidly subsiding main depocentre of the basin (Paraburdoo Member)". Conformably overlies either the Mara Mamba Iron Formation or the underlying Jeerinah Formation, suggesting the Mara Mamba Iron formation laps out or laterally interfingers with the upper Jeerinah Formation towards the basin margin (Lindsay and Brasier, 2002). Assigning to lower priority level than section DDH88BG5, which is thicker and preserves a similar d13C trend.

column36: Height between sections is approximate, but based on actual height between formations in stratigraphic column.
column40: Combines the most complete Bekker et al. (2020) sections through the Kungarra (Duck Creek Syncline) and Kazput (Hardey Syncline) Formation; location is for the Duck Creek Syncline. Using data from Bekker et al. (2020)  rather than Martindale et al. (2015) because selective sampling of more pristine samples yielded d13C values that are consistently near 0 permil, whereas Martindale et al. (2015) observe highly negative d13C values consistent with diagenetic alteration. Sections are stacked using approximate height between the uppermost sample from  the Kungarra Formation and the base of the Kazput Formation (~275 meters, Fig. 15 of Bekker et al. 2020).

(2016) suggests the Wooly Dolomite records a short-lived positive CIE around 2.03 Ga, potentially correlative to the 2.02 Ga Gumbi Group (Buick et al. 2003) (also see discussion in Magad-Weiss 2019; Fig 5.4.1). Included in the Wylo Group Composite section to enforce superpositon with the Duck Creek Dolomite.

column36: Sedimentation rate should not be calculated within the Uppermost Dolostone (above 80 meters) or the Lower Dolostone (below 2 meters). Section is also split between 2 different profiles at 15 meters. In summary: calculate sedimentation rate between 2 and 15 meters, and between 15 meters and 80 meters.
column40: Approximate location estimated from map (section 4, Figure 2 of Melezhik et al. 2015b). Superposition with the overlying Storviknes Formation is enforced by the geochronological age constraints. Using nominal Archean basement age of 2500 +/- 50 as maximum (no maximum geochronological age constraint available). Stacked Profiles B and C-D, which form a composite section through the Upper Dolostone; placed samples from the Lower Dolostone at the base, and samples from the Uppermost Dolostone at the top. Superposition between samples within the Lower Dolostone and Uppermost Dolostone sections is unknown. Estimated thickness between Profiles B and C-D based on figures, and thickness between different members is nominal; sedimentation rate should only be calculated within each original profile.

Approximate location estimated from map (Figure 2 of Melezhik et al. 2015b; coordinates for Section 7 at Raipas). Superposition with the underlying Kvenvik Formation enforced by the geochronological age constraints. Stacked Sections 6 and 7, where Section 6 "represents only the lower part of the Dolostone Member" and Section 7 "represents a 100-m thick upper part of the Dolostone member". Thickness between the stacked profiles is approximate (100 m, based on approximate location of profiles within formation); only calculate sedimentation rates within each original profile. Using nominal end-Paleoproterozoic age of 1600 +/- 50 Ma as minimum (no minimum geochronological age constraint available).

Note that although drill core 5177 intersects both the Tulomozero and Zaonega Formations, the data table in Melezhik et al. (1999) indicates that all d13C data are from the Tulomozero Formation. Assigned to priority level 2 due to similarity to OPHC core.

Location extracted from map in Melezhik et al. 2015 + visual location on satellite imagery. Only included least-altered samples, as indicated by source. Assigned to low priority level; if included in the inference, ensure that superposition with the other FAR-DEEP cores is enforced.

column40: Using location for OnZap 1 core (both OnZap 1 and OnZap 3 are approx. 500 meters from FAR-DEEP 13A). Assigned to low priority level. Most samples do not pass the authors' diagenetic screening criteria; exclude these samples if section is included in the inversion, and ensure that superposition with the underlying Tulomozero is enforced.

column39: Prave et al. (2022), Blättler et al. 2018
column40: Location estimated from map in Melezhik et al. (2015) and satellite imagery. Data from Prave et al. (2022) and Blattler et al. (2018) are from the same core; combined data from both sources. Prave et al. (2022) only includes d13C and d18O data; all other data are from Blattler et al. (2018). Strontium isotope values are age-corrected.  Sulfur isotope data are for sulfate minerals (not carbonate-associated sulfate). Calcium isotope data also are from sulfates, although some samples contain minor relict aragonite (this results in outliers, as the d44Ca signal is controlled by mineralogy rather than evaporative conditions in basin).

Sample superposition provided, but not heights (using nominal integer values). If included in the inference, ensure that superposition with the Zaonega Formation is enforced. Assigned to a lower priority than drill cores 4699 and 5177, which preserve similar stratigraphic d13C trends and include sample heights.

Sample superposition provided, but not heights (using nominal integer values). If included in the inference, ensure that superposition with the Zaonega Formation is enforced. Assigned to a lower priority than drill cores 4699 and 5177, which preserve similar stratigraphic d13C trends and include sample heights.

Location from Martin et al. (2013b) (for Drillcore 8B; 8A is in the same location, based on map in Figure 1 of Salminen et al. 2013b). Assigned to low priority level; if included in the inversion, ensure that superposition with the Kuetsjarvi Sedimentary Formation is enforced.
Location from Martin et al. (2013b). Depositional age from tuff in middle of core. Including in Pechenga Greenstone Belt Composite.

Approximate location estimated from map in Melezhik et al. (2007). Assigned to low priority level; if included in the inversion, ensure that superposition with the Kuetsjarvi Sedimentary Formation is enforced.

Approximage location estimated from map in Salminen et al. (2013b); approximately 25 km southeast of Drillcore X. Assigning to low priority level; if included in inversion, ensure that superposition with the Kolosjiki Sedimentary Formation is enforced.
Including in Pechenga Greenstone Belt Composite.

column36: Breaks already converted from depth in core to height
column39: Melezhik et al. (2005), Salminen et al. (2013b)
column40: Composite section to enforce superposition between the Kuetsjarvi and Kolosjoki Sedimentary Formations while incorporating both intermediate detrital zircon age and tuff age from Drillcore 8B. Location is for Drill Hole X.

Location of study area estimated from map. Manually stacked Lower Formation and Upper Formation (separated by a major unconformity, and approx. 300 meters of missing stratigraphy between them in stratigraphic column) to enforce superposition. Members within each formation also were stacked (heights given in meters above base of member). Therefore, sedimentation rates should only be calculated within members; thicknesses between members and between the Upper and Lower Formations are nominal. Database only includes whole-rock data (additional measurements of micro-drilled components not recorded).

Location is for section MB1601 (Kasegalik Lake), which includes the Kasegalik Formation (base of the Belcher Group); locations for all sections are provided in the supplementary information of Hodgskiss et al. (2019). Excluding post-1854 Ma samples from the uppermost unit (Loaf Formation) due to 1) lack of minimum age constraint, and 2) low carbon isotope values consistent with diagenetic alteration.

Stacked the Limestone Member (lower) and Dolostone Member (upper) to enforce superposition; nominal gap of 1 meter between formations (sedimentation rate should only be calculated within each member). Partial section through the Espanola Formation.

column33: All measurements are from the same sample
column40: Location (locality 1) extracted from Figure 1 of Hofmann and Davidson (1998) and satellite imagery. Includes four carbon isotope measurements from the same dolomitic stromatolite mound sample. Assigned to priority level 2 because 1) only a single sample was studied and 2) the stratigraphic position of the sample relative to the best available maximum age constraint for the unit (a detrital zircon maximum depositional age) is unclear.

Approximate location estimated from Fig 38 in Severson et al. (2003) (https://conservancy.umn.edu/bitstream/handle/11299/187136/TR-2003-35.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y), which also shows the locations of A-6 and BM-1.

Data extracted from Figure 6 of Bekker et al. (2006); excluded samples marked as 'most altered'. Local map coordinates are: NW1/4, Sec. 34, T.48N, R.25W).

Using location from Bekker et al. (2006). Include in inference if incoporating sulfur isotope data. d34S measurements were made on a subset of the samples from Bekker et al. (2006), but unable to combine the two sections because sample heights were not provided in Bekker et al. (2006) (data extracted from figures).

column8: Menominee and Iron River-Crystal Falls Ranges, Amasa Uplife, WI and MI
column40: Sample superposition unknown. GPS coordinates are for the general location of Loretto, Dickinson County, MI. Assigning to priority level 1 (vs. default priority level 2 for sections without superposition information) because this section includes the age constraint used to define the maximum duration of the LJE in Martin et al. (2013), and may help to constrain the timing of the LJE onset.

column9: Boxelder Formation, Estes Formation, Roberts Draw Formation
column33: Order of samples within the Estest Formation is unknown; samples from the Boxelder and Roberts Draw Formations were collected in stratigraphic order (relative positions known, but not heights)
column40: Location of general area  estimated from map; samples for each formation were collected from different sites. Stacked sections through different formations to enforce superposition. See summary of Black Hills stratigraphy and age constraints in Bekker et al. (2003). The Boxelder Formation is the oldest Paleoproterozoic unit in the Black Hills, and is conformably overlain by the Benchmark Iron Formation. The Estes Formation "unconformably overlies the Benchmark Iron Formation and Boxelder Formation", with the Roberts Draw Formation "conformably overlying the Estes Formation". Text states that "B99 samples were collected in stratigraphic order... with a sampling interval of several meters" at both locations; using nominal integer values  for heights (with a gap between formations), and assuming samples are numbered starting at the base of the section. Bekker et al. (2003) suggests that the Roberts Draw and Estes Formations correlate to the upper Nash Fork Formation, but could be younger. Superposition is not known for samples from the Estes Formation; all samples assigned to same nominal height (in between the Boxelder and Roberts Draw Formations).

Approximate location estimated from map. Data extracted from Figure 5 of Bekker et al. (2003a), and matched to samples in data table where possible; matches indicate errors of 0.1-0.2 permil are likely. Also note that "all samples are confidently assigned to members", but "for some members, poor outcrop did not permit section measuring and collected samples were tied to a generalized stratigraphic section by thier position with respect to the top or bottom of these members. In addition, samples were collected in several places within the mapped area to test variability within members" (Bekker et al. 2005). Therefore, stratigraphic superposition within each member may be uncertain. Included in Snowy Pass Supergroup Composite section.

Location is from Bekker et al. (2003b). Use section if incorporating sulfur isotope data. Stratigraphic column in supplementary information of Planavsky et al. (2012) indicates that section is through the basal L1 dolomite member (stratigraphy is as in Figure 6 of Bekker et al. 2003a).

column5: Deep Lake Group, Libby Creek Group
column39: Bekker et al. (2003a), Bekker et al. (2005)
column40: Stacked Nash Fork and Vagner Formation 1 sections to enforce superposition (see above note on confidence in sample superposition within the Nash Fork section). Location is for the Nash Fork Formation (Bekker et al. 2003b).

column2: Snowy Pass Supergroup Composite - Sierra Madre
column33: Heights given for Bottle Creek Formation samples; stratigraphic order unknown for Slaughterhouse Formation samples.
column36: Sedimentation rate should only be calculated below 20 m (within the Bottle Creek Formation); overlying Slaughterhouse Formation samples do not have superposition information.
column39: Bekker et al. (2005), Bekker et al. (2003a)
column40: Location reported as SE1/4, SE1/4, SE1/4, Sec. 17, T14N, R87W. Sample heigths are given for the Bottle Creek section, but samples from the younger Slaughterhouse Formation do not have known superposition relationship  (samples come from several outcrops in the type area). Note that some correlation schemes suggest that "the carbonate rocks and carbonaceous phyllites of the Slaugherhouse Formation in the Sierra Madre are deep-water time-equivalents of the [lower] Nash Fork Formation in the Snowy Pass Supergroup" (Bekker et al. 2006); however, this correlation is uncertain, and detrital zircon ages indicate that the Slaughterhouse Formation may be older (potentially correlative with the Gordon Lake Formation in the Huronian Supergroup; Mammone et al. 2022).

Data digitized from Figure 11 of Bekker et al. (2005). Vagner Formation 1 and 2 sections are laterally approx. 20 meters apart. Included in Snowy Pass Supergroup Composite section to enforce superposition with the younger Nash Fork Formation.

Data digitized from Figure 11 of Bekker et al. (2005). Vagner Formation 1 and 2 sections are laterally approx. 20 meters apart. Included in Snowy Pass Supergroup Composite section to enforce superposition with the younger Nash Fork Formation.

Most complete section through the Whalen Group. Location estimated from maps in Figures 8/9 of Bekker et al. (2003) and Macrostrat. Assigning to low priority level because geochronological age constraints are not available.
Location estimated from maps in Figures 8/9 of Bekker et al. (2003) and Macrostrat. Assigning to low priority level because geochronological age constraints are not available.

column39: Lajoinie et al. (2019b) (in my papers, fix refs)
column40: Location estimated from map. No uncertainty reported for maximum age constraint; using a nominal value of 50 Myr. Assigning to low priority level due to 1) uncertain maximum age, 2) probable alteration of d13C values during high-grade metamorphism, and 3) uncertainty in stratigraphy within the studied section. Because the "position of the base and top is still unknown", and primary textures are not well-preserved, it is possible that the outcrop is overturned (Lajoinie et al. 2019b).

column5: Caraça Group, Itabira Group; Piracicaba Group
column8: Hargreaves Quarry; Sabara Town; Cumbi Quarry, Drill core GDR-117
column9: Batatal Formation, Gandarela Formation; Cercadinho Formation; Fecho do Funil Formation
column39: Bekker et al. (2003b), Zhelezinskaia et al. (2014)
column40:
Section location from Nogueira et al. (2017) (Cumbi Quarry, Fecho do Funil Formation). Stacked separate sections from different formations to enforce stratigraphic superposition. Data from the carbonate interval of the Batalal Formation are from Zhelezinskaia et al. (2014), while data for all overlying units is from Bekker et al. (2003b). Sedimentation rates should only be calculated within each formation (individual formation thicknesses from Bekker et al. 2003b are >300m, so a significant amount of stratigraphy is missing). Note that there is an unconformity between the Gandarela and Cercadinho formations; Bekker et al. (2003b) notes that the Gandarela Formation could precede one of the Paleoproterozoic glacials, while the Cercadinho Formation may post-date it.

Carbon isotope values from the shale interval of the Batalal Formation (Zhelezinskaia et al. 2014) were not included in the database; d13C is highly facies-dependent, with extremely negative d13C values (-5 to -11 permil) in non-carbonate lithologies consistent with diagenetic alteration.
Approximate location estimated from map (Figure 1 of Maheshwari et al. 2010).
Approximate location estimated from map (Figure 1 of Maheshwari et al. 2010).
